Over-the-counter remedies for arthritis Search Conditions Conditions Cancer Depression Diabetes Digestive Health Healthy Living Fitness Mental Health Wellbeing Healthy Eating Medicines Medicines Aches and Pains ADHD Allergy and Asthma Brain and Nervous system Cancer Depression Privacy Notice Cookies Policy Mental health Healthy Eating Family health Conditions Follow Type keyword(s) to search Over-the-counter remedies for arthritis We look at some of the key treatments for arthritis and ask the experts what really works? [0, 0] By Adam Ramsay Rob LawsonGetty Images You can now buy hundreds of over-the-counter remedies that claim to ease the pain of arthritis. But, are they going to help or are they simply a waste of money? We look at some of the key treatments for joint pain and inflammation and ask the experts what really works? Arthritis affects around 10 million people in the UK, causing pain and inflammation of the joints, bones and muscles. It can be a debilitating disease, causing difficulty in movement and making people with arthritis less active. There are two main types: rheumatoid arthritis – an inflammatory disease – and osteoarthritis, the most common form, which develops gradually affecting mainly the hands, knees, hips, feet and spine. While there's no cure for the condition, there's plenty you can do day-to-day to manage the condition. Exercise 'Exercise is the biggest help for all forms of arthritis,' says Jo Cumming, helpline manager for charity Arthritis Care. 'The key is to get the right advice because you can do more damage than good if you overdo it – people with arthritis will have fragile joints. Things like Tai Chi, Pilates and yoga are good gentle exercises that get the joints moving, as well as helping with pain, mood and overall wellbeing.' 'Muscle strengthening is great for arthritis, especially the quad (thigh muscles) and the forearm,' says Philip Conaghan, professor of musculoskeletal medicine, University of Leeds, and spokesperson for Arthritis Research UK. 'There's lots of good trial evidence, especially regarding the benefit to knees, so it can be very useful to see a physiotherapist to give you the correct exercise.' You can see some great tailored exercises at Arthritis Research UK here. Painkillers 'Paracetamol is well tried and tested, although it doesn't work for everyone,' says Jo Cumming. 'If you're taking it a lot then you should talk with your GP, and certainly if you take anything stronger – probably containing codeine – then you should discuss it with your doctor.' 'You can take around six, 500mg paracetamol painkillers per day which can give good relief to arthritis pain,' says Professor Conaghan. 'It can be useful to think about when to take them to be most effective, such as when you are going to go to the shops or going for a walk,' he says. Anti- inflammatories 'Oral anti-inflammatories, such as low dose ibuprofen, can be very effective. But you have to watch out for stomach upsets, such as burning or bloating, and watch bowel movements because they can cause bleeding,' says Professor Conaghan. 'Make sure not to take these in combination with the prescribed medication and if you're taking them regularly, you should discuss it with your GP.' 'Non-steriodal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) help reduce the swelling around joints and are often the first line of treatment for osteoarthritis,' says Jo Cumming. 'You will often need to take stomach protecting drugs called proton-pump inhibitors as well because otherwise the side-effects can be very serious, such as gastric ulcers and high blood pressure.' Creams and gels 'These divide into two types,' says Professor Conaghan. 'The first are anti-inflammatory creams and gels, such as Voltarol emulgel and Nurofen gel, which need daily reapplying. The other type include capsaicin gels (although these can only be bought on prescription) that can take up to a week to have an effect. These can cause a burning sensation which puts some people off, but they can be effective.' Over-the-counter creams such as Transvasin and Algesal cream also create a heat sensation which can help distract the patient from the pain associated with arthritis

description: Does Tylenol manage the symptoms of osteoarthritis?
llm_response: Tylenol, also known as acetaminophen, is commonly used to manage pain, including that associated with osteoarthritis. However, a study compared the effectiveness of topical black seed oil with oral Tylenol in reducing pain in elderly osteoarthritis patients and found that black seed oil was more effective [0]. The study involved 40 elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis, divided into two groups: one group received 1 milliliter of black seed oil applied to the knee joint three times a day for 3 weeks, while the other group was given 1 tablet of 325 mg acetaminophen three times a day for the same duration [0]. The results showed that both treatments reduced pain, but the reduction was significantly greater with black seed oil (p=0.01) [0]. The researchers concluded that topical use of Nigella sativa oil (black seed oil) can be more effective in reducing knee pain in elderly patients than acetaminophen . While Tylenol can manage symptoms of osteoarthritis to some extent, the study suggests that black seed oil may offer superior pain relief without the risks associated with drug-based interventions [0, 0]. Additionally, the study highlights the potential risks of pain killers like Tylenol, which have been associated with an increased risk of serious diseases such as asthma, whereas black seed oil has been shown to reduce asthma [0]. Therefore, while Tylenol can manage osteoarthritis symptoms, it may not be as effective or safe as some natural alternatives like black seed oil.

Nostrand Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11229 Request an appointment Paracetamol Ineffective for Lower Back Pain and Arthritis, Finds Study Posted by admin on September 11, 2015 | Filed under: Healthcare News; Low back pain is a common problem that most people experience at some point in their lives while osteoarthritis, another painful condition that affects the hip and knees, is the 11th highest contributor to global disability. The first thing that most people do when they experience pain is to take a painkiller. However, a new study published in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) reports that popular painkiller Paracetamol or Tylenol (as it is also called) does not appear to reduce low back pain and offers little relief for arthritis of the hip and knees. Currently, Tylenol is recommended by most international clinical guidelines as the first line treatment for back aches and osteoarthritis. However, the study found that it is ineffective in treating back aches and provides minimal short-term benefits for people with osteoarthritis. The researchers reviewed data from 13 randomized controlled trials. They evaluated ten studies related to osteoarthritis of the hip or knee and three studies related to back pain, and examined the use of the painkiller to treat both these conditions. The study analyzed the effect the drug had on the reduction of pain intensity, improvement of disability and quality of life (along with safety and patient adherence). The key findings of the study are as follows Paracetamol was ineffective in lowering patient disability or enhancing quality of life of people with low back pain. In patients with osteoarthritis, the pain killer provided only a small, clinically insignificant improvement. The use of this medicine has direct association with higher risk of liver toxicity in patients suffering from back aches and hip and knee arthritis. Such patients were 4 times more likely to have abnormal results on liver function tests when compared to those taking placebo pills. Based on the study results, researchers urge physicians to rethink their endorsement of Paracetamol, as it is no more effective than a placebo. Moreover, the drug is linked with safety issues. The researchers suggest that physical therapy exercises, particularly strengthening exercises, are better and more effective options for managing common, painful disabling conditions. Weight control also offers important benefits for patients with arthritis. Answer: The concept of "the right to the city," as proposed by Henri Lefebvre, is fundamentally about empowering urban inhabitants to shape the city in a way that reflects their collective needs and desires, rather than being subjected to the dictates of capital and market forces. In the context of neoliberal urbanization, this right is challenged by the prioritization of economic growth and private interests over the well-being of the urban populace. Neoliberal policies often lead to the commodification of urban spaces, where the focus is on maximizing profit through real estate development, gentrification, and the creation of spaces that cater to the affluent, such as luxury apartments and commercial centers. This economic-driven approach to urban development exacerbates socio-spatial inequalities by displacing lower-income residents and marginalizing communities that do not fit into the profit-oriented vision of the city. The result is a cityscape that is increasingly divided, with stark contrasts between affluent areas and impoverished neighborhoods. The right to the city, in this context, becomes a call to action for urban dwellers to reclaim their cities from the forces of neoliberalism and to advocate for urban spaces that are inclusive, equitable, and reflective of the diverse needs of all its inhabitants. Public spaces play a crucial role in this context as they serve as platforms for interaction, expression, and the exercise of citizenship. They are the arenas where individuals and communities can come together, engage in dialogue, and collectively contribute to the cultural and social fabric of the city. By fostering a sense of belonging and enabling community engagement, public spaces help to actualize the 'right to the city' by allowing citizens to experience and influence the urban life that surrounds them. April/May 99 Newsletter From Sept/Oct '99 Back to Current Newsletter Back Issues of Newsletter "Natural" Arthritis Drugs [0, 0] As Americans age they become crippled and in pain from a disease known as osteoarthritis. The initial solution provided by most doctors is medication, like aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and Tylenol, with no long-term benefits and many serious side effects. Fortunately, there is another approach that comes close to an ideal drug therapy -- an effective therapy with few side effects. This revolutionary pill is simply nutrients for joint tissues in the formulas of glucosamine and chondroitin. Veterinarians have used these substances for years to treat the arthritic problems of animals and to prevent damage to the joints of animals, like race horses. Although usually sold in a combination of both substances as dietary supplements, there is no information available to demonstrate that the combination produces better results than glucosamine or chondroitin alone. Arthritis is ubiquitous in America: The most common form of arthritis afflicting humans is osteoarthritis, often referred to degenerative arthritis because the joints slowly degenerate as a result of "normal wear and tear associated with aging" according to most medical people. Only 2% of women less than 45 years old living in the United States show signs of osteoarthritis; eventually, this form of crippling arthritis is seen in x-rays of the hands of over 70% of people age 65 years and older. However, this same disease is comparatively rare in African and Asian countries, where people physically labor to survive (Br J Rheumatol 24:321, 1985). The reason for this, I believe, is their healthier diet that provides proper nourishment for the bones and joints. In the joints, cartilage covers the surface of the bones allowing them to effortlessly glide one bone over the other. This articular cartilage is made of two types of large molecules, proteoglycans and collagen. Proteoglycans provide elasticity and stiffness on compression; collagen provides the strength. The earliest changes in osteoarthritis are due to disruption of the collagen which contains densely packed proteoglycans. What follows is a progressive loss of the cartilage proteoglycans due to an imbalance of synthesis and degradation. The result is disruption and loss of cartilage and eventually damage to the bones. Osteoarthritis generally affects a single joint or only a few joints. Early on it is painless, but as the disease progresses the pain sends the victim to seek medical help. The pain is typically aggravated by activity and relieved by rest. In later stages the pain may persist all the time. Stiffness is common, especially upon arising in the morning. In advanced stages, gross deformity and loss of joint motion may be striking. Yet medical researchers and physicians in the United States have totally ignored this therapy, even with consistent evidence showing it is safe and effective. To date, over 300 scientific investigations and over 20 double-blind studies have been published on the use of glucosamine and chondroitin. Millions of people have tried it, and it's popularity is growing because it works. Glucosamine serves as the substrate for the building blocks of joint proteoglycans. Chondroitin is made of many glucosamine molecules, and serves the same purposes as glucosamine. Both medications lead to long-lasting pain reduction and functional improvement by increasing cartilage building activities, reducing enzymatic destruction of the cartilage, and by anti-inflammatory effects. It emphasizes the need for equitable access to urban resources and the ability to participate in shaping the urban environment. As cities become more vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, such as extreme weather events and rising sea levels, the right to the city becomes a critical framework for ensuring that all inhabitants, especially the most marginalized, have a say in the adaptation and mitigation strategies that affect their lives. This concept advocates for a more democratic and inclusive urban governance that prioritizes the well-being of all residents, ensuring that the benefits of urban life are shared and that the burdens of environmental challenges do not disproportionately fall on the poor and disenfranchised. It encourages us to consider how urban spaces are not just physical locations but are also shaped by the social and political dynamics that govern them. This perspective can lead us to advocate for more democratic processes in urban planning, where community participation is not just a formality but a fundamental aspect of decision-making. It can also inspire us to reflect on our own roles within our communities, prompting us to engage more actively in local initiatives and to support policies that aim to create equitable and sustainable urban environments. By embracing this concept, we acknowledge that cities should be built for and by their inhabitants, fostering a sense of belonging and ownership that can empower communities to shape their own futures# Student: How does the concept of "the right to the city" as proposed by Henri Lefebvre relate to the idea of urban citizenship and the role of public spaces in fostering democratic participation? Tutor: The concept of "the right to the city," as articulated by Henri Lefebvre, is intrinsically linked to the notion of urban citizenship and the significance of public spaces in promoting democratic engagement. Lefebvre's idea emphasizes the collective right of urban inhabitants to shape and use the city in a way that reflects their needs and desires, rather than being passive subjects to the forces of urbanization and capital. This right extends beyond mere access to urban resources; it encompasses the ability to participate in the decision-making processes that determine the city's development and the quality of life within it. Urban citizenship, in this context, is not just a legal status but a form of active participation in the urban life. It implies that residents have a stake in the city and should have a say in how it is governed and transformed. Public spaces play a crucial role in this dynamic as they serve as arenas for interaction, expression, and assembly. These spaces are where citizens can come together to discuss, protest, and engage with one another, thereby exercising their democratic rights and contributing to the social and political life of the city. In essence, Lefebvre's "right to the city" is about empowering urban dwellers to be co-creators of their environment, ensuring that the city remains a space of inclusivity, diversity, and democratic vitality. description: Can vitamin D supplements improve the management of asthma?
llm_response: The effectiveness of vitamin D supplements in improving the management of asthma is not definitively established, with mixed results from various studies.  1. A study pooled data from 8 clinical trials involving 1850 participants to analyze the effects of adding vitamin D to antibiotic treatment for tuberculosis, including patients with multi-drug resistant TB. It found that vitamin D accelerated the clearance of TB bacteria from the lungs of patients with multi-drug resistant TB, but this benefit was not observed in patients with standard drug-sensitive TB [1]. This suggests that the effects of vitamin D may vary depending on the condition being treated. Another study followed 545 children from the Danish COPSAC2010 cohort, who were given either a high-dose (2,800 IU/d) or standard dose (400 IU/d) of vitamin D from pregnancy week 24, to assess the impact on asthma risk. At age 3, a non-significant 24% reduced risk of recurrent asthma-like symptoms was observed in the high-dose group. However, by age 6, no effect of high-dose vitamin D supplementation on the risk of asthma was found [0]. This indicates that while there may be some potential benefits, they are not consistently significant. A clinical trial involving 955 asthma patients pooled data from 7 separate trials to determine if vitamin D supplementation protects against asthma attacks. The study found that vitamin D supplementation did not statistically reduce the number of laboratory-confirmed viral upper respiratory tract infections, which are common triggers for asthma attacks [2]. This suggests that vitamin D may not be effective in preventing asthma exacerbations triggered by viral infections. Overall, while some studies suggest potential benefits of vitamin D supplementation in certain contexts, the evidence is not conclusive, and vitamin D supplements may not consistently improve the management of asthma [0, 1, 2].

It is also worth noting that the context references other articles that discuss the effects of running and exercise on osteoarthritis, which could provide additional insights into the role of exercise in managing the condition [0]. In conclusion, while the context references suggest that exercise can be beneficial for osteoarthritis, they do not provide specific information on at-home exercises for managing hip osteoarthritis pain. For personalized advice, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional or a physical therapist who can provide guidance based on the latest research and clinical practice. Williams PT. PubMed #23377837 # Problem: How does the concept of "the right to the city" relate to the challenges faced by urban populations in the context of neoliberal urbanization and the resulting socio-economic disparities? # Solution: The concept of "the right to the city" is fundamentally about the empowerment of urban inhabitants to shape the city in a way that reflects their collective needs and desires. It is a call for a more democratic and inclusive urban environment where all residents have a say in how their city is developed and managed. In the context of neoliberal urbanization, this right is challenged by the prioritization of market-driven development and the interests of capital over those of the local population. This often leads to socio-economic disparities, as the benefits of urban development are unevenly distributed, favoring the wealthy and exacerbating the marginalization of the poor. The right to the city advocates for a reimagining of urban spaces as places of social justice and equality, where the needs of all residents, especially the most vulnerable, are addressed, and where the city serves as a collective project rather than a commodity for the few# Student: How does the concept of "the right to the city" as proposed by Henri Lefebvre relate to the idea of urban citizenship and the role of public spaces in fostering democratic participation? # TA: The concept of "the right to the city," as articulated by Henri Lefebvre, is intrinsically linked to the notion of urban citizenship and the significance of public spaces in promoting democratic engagement. Lefebvre's idea emphasizes the right of all city inhabitants to shape and use urban spaces, which is a fundamental aspect of urban citizenship. This right extends beyond mere access to include participation in the decision-making processes that determine the use and development of urban environments. Public spaces serve as the physical platforms where this right can be exercised and where urban citizenship is enacted. They are the arenas for social interaction, cultural expression, and political discourse, allowing for the visibility of diverse groups and the facilitation of collective action. In this way, public spaces are not just passive settings but active participants in the democratic process, enabling citizens to engage with one another and with the structures of power. The relationship between "the right to the city" and urban citizenship is further reinforced by the idea that the city itself is a product of its inhabitants' actions and interactions. As such, the city is a reflection of its citizens' collective will and creativity. When citizens are empowered to influence the urban landscape, they are effectively participating in the creation of their city, which is a core aspect of urban citizenship. description: Will at-home exercises manage hip osteoarthritis pain?
llm_response: At-home exercises can be an effective component in managing hip osteoarthritis (OA) pain, particularly when integrated into a multimodal physiotherapy program. The context references indicate that exercise is a recommended non-pharmacological treatment for hip OA, although the evidence supporting its effectiveness is less robust compared to knee OA [0]. A systematic review combining results from five clinical trials demonstrated a small favorable treatment effect for pain with land-based exercise, though no benefit was observed in terms of self-reported physical function [1]. Another review concluded that there was insufficient evidence to suggest that exercise therapy alone could effectively reduce pain levels, function, and quality of life in the short term [2]. However, a meta-analysis of exercise, including water-based programs, showed more favorable results for pain relief in hip OA, suggesting that therapeutic exercise, especially with specialized hand-on exercise training and an element of strengthening, is efficacious [3]. The context also highlights a high-quality randomized controlled trial where manual therapy was found to be more effective than exercise alone in managing hip OA [4]. This trial compared a 5-week manual therapy program to a therapist-supervised exercise program, with the manual therapy group showing significantly better outcomes [4]. Despite this, physiotherapy treatment often includes a combination of exercise, manual therapy, education, and advice, tailored to the individual's specific needs [0]. In the context of the referenced trial, participants in the active physiotherapy group were prescribed a home exercise program to continue after the 12-week intervention period [0]. This program included exercises such as hip abduction and knee extension strengthening, which were to be performed four times weekly [0]. The inclusion of home exercises in the treatment protocol suggests that they are considered an important part of managing hip OA pain, particularly when combined with other therapeutic components. In summary, while at-home exercises alone may not be sufficient to manage hip OA pain effectively, they are a valuable component of a comprehensive physiotherapy program that includes manual therapy, education, and other interventions. The evidence suggests that a multimodal approach, incorporating at-home exercises, can lead to significant improvements in pain and physical function for individuals with hip OA [0].
